title: What will be the outcome of Hungary's referendum on the European Union's right to set quotas for migrant relocation?
possible_answers: Turnout will reach or exceed 50% and a majority will vote "Yes"
Turnout will reach or exceed 50% and a majority will vote "No"
preds: New poll results are out today and it seems only 46% said they would definitely go.  Source: http://www.publicus.hu/blog/kvotanepszavazas_csokkeno_reszveteli_szandek_-_partok_tamogatottsaga_n/

http://hungarianfreepress.com/2016/09/28/new-poll-spells-trouble-for-orban-ahead-of-hungarys-referendum/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungarian_migrant_quota_referendum,_2016
but none of the polls forecast much over 50% of the electorate as intending to vote (and some give under 50%, as Anneiak says polls (probably) overstate the likelihood that voters will actually turn out. 
In previous referendums in Hungary the turnout has not been nearly as high as in elections and most have failed to achieve the 50%. 
There seems to be little motivation for voters to bother to go to the polling station. According to The Economist a NO vote that beats a YES vote by a significant percentage sends a clear message to the EU regardless of the turnout being a few percentage points above or below 50%. Getting 75% voting NO on a 40% turnout gets the message across as clearly as getting 60% NO on a 51% turnout. That message is that the EU telling Hungary to accept a fixed number of refugees is not popular in Hungary. It does not appear that getting over 50% would actually trigger anything. The EU plan to direct countries to take refugees is probably already dead.

Newest poll suggests 61% will vote for No with turnout of likely voters at 54%.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungarian_migrant_quota_referendum,_2016 Yes is clearly impossible, but whether or not turnout exceeds 50% is hardly certain.

http://hungarianfreepress.com/2016/09/28/new-poll-spells-trouble-for-orban-ahead-of-hungarys-referendum/ New poll spells trouble for Orbán ahead of Hungary’s referendum
September 28, 2016 4:39 pm· "Prime Minister Viktor Orbán’s national referendum . . . scheduled for October 2nd, will likely be invalid, with fewer than 50% of eligible voters casting ballots. The Medián polling firm–perhaps the most reputable pollster in Hungary–was commissioned by the hvg.hu news site to conduct a poll less than a week before the national referendum. Only 42% of respondents indicated that they planned to participate in the Sunday plebiscite, falling well short of the minimum 50%-plus-one threshold. But of those participating, fully 83% plan to heed Prime Minister Orbán’s call and will vote “no” to EU migrant “quotas.” Only 13% will vote “yes” and 3% plan to cast an invalid ballot. " . . .  the proportion of left-wing voters that actually plans to cast a ballot on Sunday hovers at just 20%. The Hungarian Socialist Party (MSZP), the Democratic Coalition (DK) and the Együtt (Together) party have all called on their supporters to boycott the referendum. "The Medián poll cautions that the most recent figures may not reflect any potential impact from this past weekend’s explosion in Budapest and heightened fears surrounding public safety and terrorism. But Mr. Orbán, after not commenting on the bombing for 65 hours, did finally come out and note that there is no correlation between the incident and the refugee/migrant crisis. “Although we can’t completely rule it out, there are no signs to the contrary at this time, and this is reassuring,” said Mr. Orbán. The prime minister added that he instructed Interior Minister Sándor Pintér to “hunt down” the perpetrator and to “extract from him” the reasons behind his attack.
~~~~~~~

1990 presidential election referendum turnout: 14%
1997 NATO membership referendum turnout: 49.2%
2003 referendum on EU membership turnout: 45.6%
2004 dual citizenship referendum turnout: 37.5%
2008 fees abolition referendum turnout: 50.5% Given historically <50% turnout in Hungarian referendums on emotive and significant issues (EU and NATO membership), a less than 50% turnout for this referendum remains a significant possibility. However, given how controversial the migrant issue has proven to be and growing resentment against EU reforms seen as assaults on sovereignty it seems more likely that a >50% turnout will occur.

http://hungarianfreepress.com/2016/09/16/hungarys-anti-migrant-referendum-the-most-recent-poll-and-what-religious-leaders-are-saying/ "A new poll by Republikon suggests that 48% of the electorate is certain to cast a ballot, while an additional 23% say that they will likely vote. . . .  (73% will vote ‘no’ according to Republikon) and the referendum may also be valid, with participation surpassing the 50% + 1 threshold. But Republikon also cautions that it is notoriously difficult to accurately gauge participation levels through polls. Many Fidesz voters, who are the most likely to cast a ballot in the referendum, may simply feel social pressure to tell pollsters that they will vote, when in fact they have little inclination to actually do so. In other words, participation levels reported by pollsters may be overestimated. "Additionally, now that left-centre opposition parties have launched a more visible campaign advocating for Hungarians to boycott the vote . . . The proportion of voters who intend to boycott the vote increased from 17% to 21% over the last month.
. . .

http://bbj.hu/politics/despite-aggressive-government-campaign-hungarians-unsure-of-referendum_121832 "Both at the end of July and August, approximately 53% of Hungarians said they were planning to participate in the referendum on October 2, although only 41% now say they are sure about how they will vote, the representative research by Závecz Research shows, according to index.hu.   "Figures show that no rise in the number of voters planning to participate in the referendum has been measured, despite the aggressive campaign the governing party Fidesz launched in August, criticized by many as propaganda. According to Hungarian media reports, Fidesz is planning to make the campaign supporting the governmentʼs stance in the referendum even more aggressive in the coming weeks." " . . . it is currently impossible to tell whether the referendum will be valid or not, it is likely that less than half of Hungarians with eligibility to vote will participate, according to Tibor Závecz, chief of Závecz Research. “It is doubtful, but not impossible that the referendum will be valid, but if the campaign Fidesz is currently running does not become stronger, and if the campaign of the opposition becomes more visible, there is a high probability that the referendum will not be valid,” Závecz told index.hu. "While opposition parties urge Hungarians not to attend as insufficient turnout would make the vote invalid, NGOs have recently been encouraging Hungarian voters to participate in October’s referendum, but to hand in invalid votes, to demonstrate opposition to the government’s stance on refugees. . . .  according to the poll commissioned by index.hu, the proportion of those planning to attend and cast invalid votes is very low.

The ‘no’ vote is supported by Jobbik, while the rest of the opposition is divided between boycotting the referendum (Socialists, Democratic Coalition, Dialogue for Hungary, and the Together party), leaving it up to their voters (Politics Can Be Different), and campaigning for ‘yes’ (Liberals). The ‘no’ vote is supported by Jobbik, while the rest of the opposition is divided between boycotting the referendum (Socialists, Democratic Coalition, Dialogue for Hungary, and the Together party), leaving it up to their voters (Politics Can Be Different), and campaigning for ‘yes’ (Liberals).  A majority of ‘no’ votes thus seems inevitable, although a valid result is not yet assured.

Turnout in Hungarian referendums since 1997 have been 49.2%, 45.6%, 37.5%, and 50.5%. Weighted due to relevance and how recent the referendums took place, I developed a weighted average of c.42%. The average turnout intention in polling for the referendum has been  51%. With the absence of any empirical data, I take both these percentages to be of equal weight, giving me an estimated turnout percentage of 46.5%. This should be tempered by the fact that these referendums have been votes "for" something rather than "against" as is the case here. All this being said, the likelihood of turnout exceeding 50% is in my view, 35%. All polls have pointed to "no" gaining between 64% and 87% of the vote. Among polls with 1000 sample size and allowing for undecideds, the "no" vote looks likely to be in the high 60s or low 70s. All this being said, the likelihood a majority will vote "no" is 90%. That therefore gives the answers of 3%, 32% and 65%, with the vote failing to reach the threshold as the most likely answer.

EU-imposed quotas is a very unpopular issue and no one is spending political capital arguing in favour of them. Even the pro-EU forces are concentrating mainly on a boycott campaign. As such, while not impossible, a "Yes" victory is a very remote possibility. Hungarians historically do not turnout en masse for single-issue referenda, which would suggest a high probability the 50% threshold won't be reached. However, the "No" campaigners are spending a lot of effort elevating this vote to a proxy for the relationship with Brussels as a whole. Given how successful this tactic was in the Netherlands during the recent referendum on the EU-Ukraine association agreement, and how polarising the migration question and the EU currently are throughout Eastern Europe, I give a lower, but still high, chance that the threshold won't be reached.

-NATO membership referendum in 1997 (1 question, passed)
-European Union membership referendum in 2003 (1 question, passed)
-Dual citizenship referendum in 2004 (2 questions, both failed because of low voter turnout)
-Fees abolishment referendum in 2008 (3 question, all passed) The current referendum does not really cover the EU refugee mandate:
From: http://thewire.in/63064/the-cynical-thinking-behind-hungarys-bizarre-referendum/
"The first thing to note about this vote is the question on the ballot paper. It is so biased and misleading, it’s hard to imagine how it was even allowed:
“Do you want the European Union to be entitled to prescribe the mandatory settlement of non-Hungarian citizens in Hungary without the consent of parliament?”
"The EU is not forcing Hungary to accept mandatory settlement of refugees. Brussels is only requesting that Budapest should process their applications and to decide whether they are eligible for asylum."

The polls seem to predict a clear "No". The questions has been framed to enourage a "No". If we assume that the governing party (Fidesz) and the far right (Jobbik) party's voters will vote "No" that would give about 65% of the electorate.  In parliamentary elections there has been over 60% turnout. Right wing, populist and nativist rhetoric has been getting good results in polls in the last few years (Trump in primaries, Brexit, Le Pen etc.) The only likely way for "No" to "lose" would be if the third of voters who did not support Feidesz or Jobbik boycotted the referendum or spoiled their ballot papers. If they all did this "No" could overwhelmingly win the vote, but the total number of votes would be below the 50% threshold and nullify the result. It sets a risky precedent to tell your supports not to turn up to vote.  So far some opposition parties are urging a boycot or to spoil the ballot but others are telling supporters to vote "yes".

In the last five referendums in Hungary (on varying issues), turnout has been: 50.5%, 37.5%, 45.6% (joining the EU), 49.2% (joining NATO), and 14%. In the last five General Elections, turnout has been: 61.8%, 64.4%, 67.6%, 70.5% and 57.0%. In the last three EU Parliament elections, turnout has been 29.0%, 36.3% and 38.5%. Polling on this referendum is heavily in favour of 'No'. But various polls have shown expected turnout above and below the 50% mark: in August alone, one has it at 43% and another at 54%. Taking a range of recent polls, and excluding outliers, I got an average turnout estimate of 50.8%! Generally they have suggested >50%, but the direction of travel appears to be downwards. Immigration is a highly emotive issue in Hungary, which may suggest high turnout. But, polls heavily in favour of one side or the other can quell voter turnout too. This could be tipped by an event in the next month, e.g. another terror attack in Europe.

1.Hungarian presidential election referendum, 1990
Turnout was just 14% https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungarian_European_Union_membership_referendum,_2003
2.voter turnout of 45.6% https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungarian_dual_citizenship_referendum,_2004
3.voter turnout of 37.5 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Referendums_in_Hungary 3/6 times Hungary has held referendums, turnout was insufficient. But immigration is a hot button issue, and regardless of left parties urging a boycott people are likely to vote strongly against it.
Referendum turnouts are always lower than elections. And 50% is putting the bar veryyy high.

Opinion polls, without exception, show the "no" vote well out in front (see summary in Hungarian at https://hu.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016-os_magyarorsz%C3%A1gi_n%C3%A9pszavaz%C3%A1s): the lowest % in favour of no given so far is 77%. The question is really whether turnout will reach 50% or not. The same opinion polls referenced above are rather cagier on this:  of the six polls conducted listed above, conducted since May measuring willingness to participate, four give figures above 50%, and two - tellingly the most recent polls, at the end of July and in August, are below 50% (at 42% and 43%). Past precedent - referendums.
2008, on abolition of some medical and student tuition fees: rate of turnout 50.5%
2004, on ownership of public health bodies and permitting certain kinds of dual citizenship: 37.5%
2003, on joining the European Union: 45.6%
1997, on joining NATO: 49.2% These figures are not terribly helpful. One might think the migration issue was at least as much an emotive, heartfelt, and to some degree irrational issue as  were the questions of EU or NATO membership. All three issues are deeply tied up with questions of national sovereignty and self-determination, particularly in a country that has known foreign oppression in the very recent past, and which has lost substantial territories to neighbouring countries (particularly under the Treaty of Trianon), the loss of which are still keenly felt by a non-negligiable section of the population. (Jobbik's rise in recent years in part relates to this, and its offshoot "64 county sovereignty body" referring to those former Hungarian counties now outside the country, but which retain substantial ethnically Hungarian populations) .    The context of contemporary migration quotas, in the face of large-scale migration from the Middle East/Syria also relates to a context in Hungary in which specifically Islamic oppression (during the period of Ottoman rule) is a fundamental part of the national story. And moreover, nationalism has been a fairly powerful, and vocal, force in Hungary in recent years - since around 2006 on, in particular. Yet the EU and NATO membership referendums, admittedly held before this upsurge in nationalism, and without this Islamic aspect to them, failed to attract 50%  of voters... (whereas a more technical referendum, in 2008  narrowly did so.) On the basis of past referendum turnouts, solely, I am inclined to suspect that surpassing the 50% turnout threshold will be a challenge. Also supporting this thesis: consistently low rates of turnout at European Parliamentary elections (in common with other Central European states): 38.5% in 2004, 36.3% in 2009, 29.0% in 2014.
And similarly in local elections: , 53.1% in 2006 (at time of heightened political activity and demonstration), 46.6% in 2010, 44.3% in 2014. Parliamentary elections typically show a higher turnout: 70.5% in 2002, 67.8% in 2006, 64.4% in 2010, 61.7% in 2014.  A general and persistent downturn is evident, though. At the 2014 election, 44.9% of voters supported the Fidesz-led coalition, 20.2% the far-right Jobbik, and 5.3% the environmentalist LMP, all of whom support the "no" option in the referendum (=70.4% of voters in 2014  = 43.4% of the registered electorate).
Conversely, 25.6% of 2014 voters (15.8% of the registered electorate) supported the Unity coalition, which is urging a boycott of the poll.  Purely on the basis of past electoral form, and the most recent opinion polls, the 50% threshold will be hard to cross.  The case against seems mainly emotional, and related to on the one hand the levels of nationalist rhetoric that has been used in various government and opposition campaigns (posters for example; and the construction of barriers and barbed-wire fences at national borders); and on the other to (possibly exaggerated or not fully rational)  concerns about the prospects of Islamic terrorism being introduced to Hungary by potential future migrants - recent attacks in Germany, France, Belgium may be in mind.  Images of lawless crowds of young men  breaking down barriers, and memories of encampments of migrants in Budapest last summer may also bring out voters.  Conversely, compassion for genuine refugees - again in a country and of a people that itself has had a turbulent history (and which itself ultimately is of non-European origin) might encourage the vote to be boycotted, given the opinion polls universally showing the "no" vote well out in front... I am going to look further for evidence in support of things that might push the turnout up over 50%.  At present most rational, quantifiable, evidence suggests this will not be the case. However, this may be the sort of issue at which rational analysis is not the key point.

No question that the No votes will carry the day.  Crossing the 50% mark also appears to be on target.   This is a question of national control and appealing to the Hungarian general population by giving them a say in this issue.

From the link: "Turnout is predicted to comfortably surpass the 50 per cent required to make it valid under the country’s laws." 
https://www.theparliamentmagazine.eu/articles/news/poll-hungary-largely-reject-fresh-influx-migrants-october-referendum It seems clear from the reports that a majority of the voters will vote "No". 
The key question is, will 50% of eligible voters participate? If they do turn out in the required numbers (the link reports that 54% intend to vote) then the referendum passes. However, if the percent of eligible voters is < 50%, the referendum fails.
